title: all the planks on love island ally
story: Having force-fed the Suffragettes, back in the last century, it’s now the Suffragettes’ turn to force-feed us, in 2018. An endless, choking diet of documentaries, live events, lectures, news items and outright bollockings, from the BBC, all to celebrate the 100th anniversary of women getting the vote.Not one of which had as much impact as Love Island’s “Girl Power” task on ITV2, involving super-hero capes, bikinis, large items of fruit and narrator Iain Stirling explaining: “The girls will squish melons with their bums. Slowest girl to crush her melon is out of the contest.”Just part of the reason I adore a show which pricks pomposity and political correctness like ­nothing else on British television and is dedicated to no other purpose than entertaining its viewers. That’s the ideal, anyway.The reality’s been a bit more disappointing, so far, probably due to the excessive hype and sense of deja vu with contestants on either half of the gender divide.Both operate a squad rotation system, of course, but among the main players on the blokes’ side, we have painfully shy ­doctor Alex, with all the presence of a fire extinguisher, Jack who “got his teeth in Turkey”, possibly by ripping them from a feral mountain goat’s mouth, and this year’s comedy figure Niall, who’s “an investment for the future”, a bit like Betamax video tapes, and “multi-layered”, like a landfill site.There’s the compulsory personal trainer, as well, of course — Adam, who seems to have the run of the females, plus strong silent type Wes and fluffy-haired Eyal, pronounced “Eeeeh-al”, “Oooh-all”, or just “Aaaah-sole”, if you prefer.Quite the ­profound one, is Eyal, forever banging on about “auras” and his spirituality while insisting: “I want to find someone here with depth.”A claim which, surely, represents the very height of human optimism given the most profound question all of the girls were asking last week was: “Where’s your head at?”In Kendall’s case, it was “literally all over the place”. One of her eyes was in Majorca, another in Ibiza and her ­forehead was somewhere in the Cote d’Azur. She’s gone though now, leaving, among significant others: Samira, Georgia, Rosie, super- manipulative Hayley and Laura, a former air stewardess who’s ­covered in more make-up than the giraffe in a theatre ­production of The Lion King.Most of the hype, however, has centred around the ­presence of Dani Dyer, the daughter of EastEnders actor Danny Dyer. But you knew that already, didn’t you, possibly because you read it in the paper and possibly because you saw her perform exactly the same big reveal on ITV2’s Survival Of The Fittest a couple of months ago. A doubling up that blows my mind, frankly.Because you expect hit shows to be copied by other fringe channels.What you don’t expect is ITV2 to abuse the basic law of ­supply and demand by copying its own format. A move that doesn’t help Love Island at all. It stops it being an event, in fact, and just makes viewers think this sort of crap is on all year.Personally, I think that’s a shame. Love Island genuinely deserves to be a huge success again. Not only is it one of the funniest and most UN-PC shows on TV, it’s also a series that can actually make you feel glad to be old and half-crippled by your medical complaints, rather than the youthful insecurity and stupidity which has gripped this bunch, who really did surpass themselves, on Friday.Georgia: “What do you think of Brexit?”Hayley: “What’s that?”“We’re leaving the EU so things like welfare and, like, things we trade with would all be cut down.”“So that means we wouldn’t have any trees?”“Cheese?” “No, trees.” “Oh.”Emmeline Pankhurst, your work here on Earth was not in vain.(Love Island, ITV2, 9pm).HAVING discovered Danny Dyer is the rightful heir to the English throne, BBC1 really should’ve knocked it on the head with Who Do You Think You Are?Until such time as one of the researchers can prove Danniella Westbrook is the rightful heir to the Romanov dynasty and the Imperial Highness of all Russia.So they must have been flipping cartwheels at HQ when they discovered the great-great-grandmother of this week’s guest, ex-Corrie star Michelle Keegan had her birth certificate signed by registrar Emmeline Pankhurst, leader of the Suffragettes.A much greater honour, in the Beeb’s book, than three wise men and some shepherds turning up at your crib, but a detail that was probably as dull as ditch water for most viewers.The far more interesting thing to emerge during the hour, I thought, was Michelle’s own staggering ignorance of life, the world and everything.She had, for instance, no idea where Genoa was and gave a genuinely staggering response when a local historian told her: “By 1940 your family will have been torn apart, like every other family in Gibraltar, at the time.”“Why?”(Pause) “The Second World War.”You wondered then if the show would ever get round to revealing if the plank gene had entered her family tree through the maternal or paternal line.Then Michelle Skyped her mum and, waving a frothy cup of coffee at the screen, said: “Guess where I am. I’ll give you a clue, I’m drinking a cappuccino . . . ”“France?”Mystery solved.Loose Women, Russell Brand, with Janet Street-Porter: “Everyone is so beautiful here.”Good Morning Britain, roly-poly Piers Morgan: “When I grew up, I loved Frosties and it never did me any harm.”And Love Island, Samira: “I can sing, I can dance, I can act.” (Bursts into song).She can’t sing.NEVER, in all its ten-series history, has ITV’s love lift been quite as badly needed as it was on Saturday’s brilliant, one-off Take Me Out special for the “over-50s”.A slightly generous description, I thought, given the 30 game old birds looked like they had the combined age of the Pyramids.The fire still burns down below, though, evidently, as a queue of lights remained on for George, the midget Zumba teacher with the wooden teeth, Lawrence, the Billy Connolly lookalike from Ibiza, and even “bouncing Bill”, the ex-policeman, above, who emerged from Paddy McGuinness’s love lift gasping for breath and telling the women: “Every night, when I go to sleep, I like to think I’ve made someone’s life better. What would your motto be?”Fingers crossed, I’d imagine.Lee Dixon: “I like Alexander-Arnold because he gives you half a goal.”Ian Wright: “Harry Kane is still getting back to where he is.”And Glenn Hoddle: “By the time the World Cup starts, today will be history.”(Compiled by Graham Wray)Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “In 1883 which luxury train service ran between Paris and the city now called Istanbul?” Alice: “The Eurostar.”Ben Shephard: “The former Labour MP Ed Balls married which politician in 1998?” Phil: “Theresa May.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The plumage of what flightless bird was used as a medieval helmet decoration?” Geoff: “Eagle.”And Ben Shepherd: “How many of the eight planets in our solar system have the letter A in their name?”Harj: “I think the answer to that is one. Aries.”From A Girl’s Guide to TV, Rachel Parris’s uncompromising attack on institutionalised television sexism and cry for liberation from the patriarchy.Co-written by Tom Neenan and pro- duced by Adam Reeve.The sheer pleasure of looking at next week’s BBC schedules without seeing the word Glastonbury.Sky Arts repeating Tales Of The Unexpected.Take Me Out’s grab-a-granny special. Love Island’s Hayley asking: “What does superficial mean?” Richard Madeley’s barn-storming Question Time performance.And every sad, funny, touching detail of John MacLaverty’s epic Scotland 78: A Love Story, on BBC1, apart from the fantasy sequence where we beat Holland 4-1 and make the final.Too soon, John. Too bloody soon.BBC2, A Girl’s Guide To TV: “Hello, I’m Rachel Parris, I’m a woman and there’s absolutely no getting away from that.”Click.THIS week’s winner is Eyal off Love Island and Mr Tumnus from The Chronicles Of Narnia. Sent in by Jordan Fletcher, of Mansfield, Notts.Picture research: Amy Reading.Channel 5 contin- uity: “First, with a look at rare and dangerous eating disorders, which viewers should not try to emulate, it’s The Woman Who Ate A House.”And I could’ve murdered a bungalow as well.The One Show exposing viewers to Elaine Paige’s hideous cartoon death gurgle of a laugh.People like Love Island’s Eyal, who have “auras” and “energies” rather than a personality.The desperation of New World Order guest Richard Osman to be part of the BBC’s left-wing comedy gang reaching the “God bless him, Jeremy Corbyn” stage.BBC1 News offering a typically sniffy and disapproving obituary for the remarkable Peter Stringfellow.And Take Me Out’s over-50s special proceeding without Paddy McGuinness honouring the occasion with the legend: “Shingles man, reveal yourself.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: collection of eight stamps issued for 50th anniversary of dads army
story: The collection features the main characters and their catchphrases from the BBC series – which ran from 1968 to 1977 – including Corporal Jones and his call of “Don’t panic!”.Ian Lavender, 72, who played Private Pike and is the only surviving main cast member, said: “I didn’t believe you could have someone still alive on a stamp apart from the Queen.“You can hope for an OBE or a Bafta. But to be on a stamp, well it really is so nice.”Dad’s Army followed the mishaps of a Second World War Home Guard platoon commanded by pompous bank manager Captain Mainwaring, assisted by his mild-mannered chief clerk, Sergeant Wilson. title: five steps to the best brexit deal
story: A lack of preparation in customs threatens the UK’s leverage in our negotiation with the EU. He also analyses Irish border ­protocol, the cost of customs clearance and how we can ­maximise Brexit opportunities.Under the proposed New Customs Partnership, the UK would collect tariffs on all imports into the EU regardless of whether they are then exported to EU27 ­countries or are meant for UK consumption.If goods are only for UK consumption, then importers may claim a rebate. This option was voted against in the Brexit Cabinet but seems to have a zombie-like resiliency so cannot be discounted entirely.It would mean the end of UK independent trade policy and be disastrous for prosperity.No, it’s not lippy. Max Fac is short for maximum facilitation, referring to the process of creating a border between the EU and the UK which is as frictionless as possible.This is achieved by waiving duties on goods and employing technology-based solutions to ensure smoother border crossing.The customs facilitation chapter will ensure both sides mutually recognise each other’s trusted trader programmes – something the EU does with many countries – and optimise the customs process.The Irish border problem has been a crunch point, with some claiming there would have to be border controls between Ireland and Northern Ireland.But it is not insurmountable.Some sort of customs checks on goods crossing the border would be needed, but not necessarily passport checks or everyone being stopped.The use of technology is very important — it is ­constantly improving, lowering customs barriers.Much has been made of the cost to businesses of completing customs declaration forms after Brexit.Estimates as high as £20billion have been doing the rounds but a more ­realistic figure is closer to £4billion or £5billion.The whole point of Brexit, from an economic perspective, is to offset these losses with the gains from an independent trade policy.Economic studies suggest an improvement of EU regulations to US levels would lead to a gain of 12.6 per cent of GDP (approximately £250bn for our economy).The actual costs of leaving the customs union and single market (tariffs, clearance costs and the costs of lack of regulatory recognition) need better context.With customs, the costs of clearance in terms of increased form-filling is dwarfed by the opportunities that better regulation at home, and reducing barriers abroad, can achieve. Of course we should minimise these costs — and “max fac” is designed to do just that.But we must also understand what the opportunities are for the country. Our policies should pursue these opportunities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour prepare for brexit split
story: Despite a last-minute plea from Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer, Europhile Labour MPs vowed to support a Lords amendment calling for membership of the European Economic Area.At the same time as many as 10 Labour MPs could side WITH the Government to back Theresa May’s Brexit plans and ensure they pass. Led by Caroline Flint, the Brexit-backing MPs have sent a stinging letter to Jeremy Corbyn urging him not to bow to pressure from pro-EU colleagues.EEA membership gives countries such as Norway and Liechtenstein access to the single market, but they have to accept unlimited EU immigration and EU rules and regulations. Jeremy Corbyn wants his MPs to back separate Labour plans for a bespoke Brexit deal that would guarantee the UK full access to the single market.But leading Labour backbenchers including Chuka Umunna, Mary Creagh and Chris Leslie, are among the 70 expected to defy him.The tension on the Labour benches erupted on Sunday when Mr Leslie had a bitter TV dust-up with Brexit-backing Caroline Flint.After saying Ms Flint of sounding like arch Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees Mogg, she accused him of sounding “desperate”. Ms Flint - a former Labour Europe Minister - was one of a cluster of Labour MPs from Leave constituencies urging Jeremy Corbyn not to bow to pressure from Europhiles.In the letter, the MPs, including Gareth Snell, said backing EEA membership would force the UK to continue to accept unlimited EU migration. Another split emerged as the TSSA Union became the first Labour affiliated union to call for a referendum on the Brexit deal agreed with Brussels.One source told The Sun: “The party is split two to three ways. And it’s great fun for the Corbynistas – they’re watching the MPs who wanted him out scrapping with each other.”Sir Keir Starmer met a group of Europhile Labour MPs before he addressed the full Labour Parliamentary Party.One insider said he hinted Labour could move closer to backing EEA membership next month when both the Government’s Customs and Trade Bills go before the Commons.The UK Chamber of Shipping urged MPs to reject any Norway-style deal.The trade body said: “We cannot allow the UK to become the only major economy in the world to have no say in the rules and regulations its economy lives.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hilarious moment people realised their school friends were posh
story: However, for some people, those childhood memories came with hilarious realisations that some of our friends are just that bit posher than the rest.Twitter users have been sharing their own memories of growing up and their hilarious tales of discovering that some of their friends were the fancy kind.From having more than one type of cheese in the house to being offered starters at the dinner table, comedian Sam Whyte received a flurry of responses when she asked her followers what their particular lightbulb moment was.Posing the question to her 4,500 followers, she wrote: “When you were a kid, how did you know someone was a bit posh when you went round their house? So far weve got more than one type of cheese in the fridge and booze that wasnt for drinking that day.”The responses did not disappoint, with more than one bathroom, the ownership of a Soda Stream and having a remote controlled television a sign of money in the 70s and 80s. The Manchester-based comedian’s question soon went viral, with her adding: “Whilst a lot of this is clearly confined to a moment in history, taking your shoes off to go in seems to be a constant.”Other trips down memory lane revealed that owning a leather sofa, a colour television, and even napkins rings were the reserve of the posh.Some marvelled in the variety of puddings on offer at their friends’ homes, while others revelled in the idea of fresh spaghetti instead of the tinned variety.Houses with names and the appearance of a roasted suckling pig at a birthday party left others in awe, while the appearance of a housekeeper left one guy questioning what a normal childhood was supposed to look like.

title: mothers who choose to bottle feed babies must be respected says royal college of midwives
story: She said: "I did feel a complete failure by formula feeding him, and I was made to feel like that by the GPs I visited and things."But, as far as I could see, I couldn't find a way through it. The support's not there. So we've got the drop-in centres, and obviously there's the infant feeding teams in the hospitals."But women and mums need that support every single day, for the first few weeks when a baby arrives."Sarah McMullin, head of research at the National Childbirth Trust (NCT), said that the new wording was welcome but that the guidelines on breastfeeding were still outdated.She said: "At the moment it doesn't feel realistic for women to feed through days, weeks, six months, never mind two years."I think the important thing is we take a really one-to-one, individual approach, helping women to feed for as long as they would like to, and that they're both supported to breastfeed when they want to, and also feel supported when they make a decision to stop at a time that's right for them."According to the RCM, breastfeeding positively influences inpatient admission rates in the early weeks of life for respiratory and gastric conditions, and reduces the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

title: brexit votes explained theresa faces
story: News15 showdown Brexit votes could change the course of leaving the EU this week - this is how they'd hit youTheresa May faces a showdown with her own MPs over the EU Withdrawal Bill, which was heavily amended in the Lords. It's really important - but it's going to get confusing. Bluff your way through the drama here&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter08:33, 12 JUN 2018NewsTheresa May is facing a massive headache, and so are you - so we've made it easy to bluff (Image: AFP)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is facing a major Commons showdown over Brexit this week. And it won't just make or break her premiership - it could have a huge difference to you, your family, and your everyday life. That's because in a string of votes, MPs will choose whether to carry on with the Prime Minister's current Brexit plan or make it much, much softer. Mrs May is pulling out all the stops to prevent a Tory Remainer revolt that would scupper her Brexit talks, and leave Britain closer to the EU. The drama will take place on Tuesday 12 June and Wednesday 13 June.  It's all centred around 15 amendments to the EU Withdrawal Bill , which is Mrs May's flagship law enacting Brexit. If the amendments pass, they could keep us in the customs union and very nearly in the single market - forcing us to stick to EU rules. This is the opposite of what the Prime Minister wants.  These amendments aren't the end of the road - there are more votes on customs next month - but they're a huge step along the road. So we've gone through all 15 to explain simply what they mean. Enjoy!  What were the 15 defeats to the EU Withdrawal Bill? Your Brexit votes bingo card MPs are holding a marathon two-day voting session on June 12-13 as Theresa May tries to overturn 15 defeats to her Brexit law. The amendments, passed by the House of Lords, would push Britain towards a softer Brexit if they are not blocked by the House of Commons. But it's going to be massively confusing. Who's voting on what, when? To help you follow the drama, here's a list of the original 15 Lords defeats to the EU (Withdrawal) Bill - and what they'll achieve if they pass. For geeks, each amendment's 'number' is in brackets. As if it wasn't confusing enough, each one gets 'renumbered' so we've included both numbers - the old number, followed by the new number. Some of these will be defeated, some could pass. Four we've marked with asterixes (*) - these are ones where the government has offered a compromise to get them through.  Customs Union: Would force Tory ministers to take steps towards staying in an EU Customs Union - by making a statement on how they'd do it. This could stop Britain from striking trade deals around the world - but would prevent a hard border in Northern Ireland and keep free trade with the EU. (1, 1) Single market: Would force the Tory government to keep Britain in the European Economic Area (EEA) - which practically means keeping membership of the single market, and following nearly all its rules. This would likely continue free movement between Britain and the EU - almost as we see it today. (110A, 51) Meaningful vote*: Would give MPs a 'meaningful vote' in Autumn 2018 on Theresa May's Brexit deal. It could force her back to the negotiating table instead of crashing out with no deal. Backers insist they wouldn't use it to 'stop Brexit' - but that's exactly what Leavers fear will happen. (49, 19) Brexit Day: Would remove the legal date of Brexit - 29 March 2019 - to let ministers change the date at the last minute if they don't have a deal. Leavers also fear this could be a tool to delay Brexit indefinitely. (95, 37) Northern Ireland*: Would give added protection to the Northern Ireland border - forcing ministers to obey the Good Friday Agreement, and keep the province in an EU customs union if it stops a hard border. (88, 25) Henry VIII powers 1: Would block Tory ministers from changing EU laws on several issues - employment, equality, health and safety, environmental or consumer rights - without enhanced scrutiny by MPs. (11, 4) Henry VIII powers 2: Would block ministers having a wide-ranging power to decide when EU laws can be challenged after Brexit. (18, 52) Henry VIII powers 3: Limits ministers' power to change law without a vote - they'd only be able to do it if necessary, instead of if appropriate. (31, 10) Henry VIII powers 4: Would give a 'sifting committee' of MPs the power to insist Parliament gets a vote on legal changes. (70, 110) Refugees' rights*: Would continue refugees' rights to be reunited with their families in the UK under the EU's Dublin Regulation. (59, 24) Citizens' EU legal rights*: People could continue suing the government in UK courts for breaching general principles of EU law. (19, 53) Charter of Fundamental Rights: Would ensure the vast majority of the EU's Charter stays in UK law. (15, 5) Theresa May's mandate: Would force the PM to get MPs' approval for her 'mandate' for Britain's future relationship with the EU. (51, 20) Future EU laws: Would let ministers copy and paste new EU laws into UK law after Brexit, and carry on taking part in EU agencies. (93, 32) Protecting the environment: Would block ministers from using Brexit to water down any protections for the environment. (1, 3)

title: theresa said inquiry alleged links
story: NewsTheresa May said an inquiry into alleged links between Russia and the campaign to leave the European Union were a “matter for the police”Arron Banks dismissed reports of links with the Russians in the lead up to the 2016 referendum as a “smear”&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent21:15, 11 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May said calls for an inquiry into alleged links between Russia and the campaign to leave the European Union were a “matter for the police”.  The Prime Minister was asked whether it was time for a “full police inquiry” following reports that the millionaire Brexit backer Arron Banks had more extensive contact with the Kremlin than previously acknowledged.  It comes as Mr Banks dismissed reports of links with the Russians in the lead up to the 2016 referendum as a “smear”. According to the Sunday Times, Mr Banks - the Leave.EU founder who helped bankroll Nigel Farage’s campaign - held a series of undisclosed meetings with Russian embassy officials around the time of the 2016 referendum campaign. The paper said it had seen emails showing he also discussed a potential business deal involving six Russian gold mines with ambassador Alexander Yakovenko after being introduced to him by a suspected Russian spy.  The billionaire said a witch hunt against Russian power had begun after Donald Trump’s election victory and the vote to Leave the EU.  Speaking alongside his former aide Andy Wigmore on Nigel Farage’s LBC radio show, Mr Banks said: “It was only when Trump won and there had to be a reason why he won - and Brexit.” The pair admitted having lunch with the Russian ambassador twice - one of which was described as a “boozey lunch” where they drank vodka, brandy and wine - as well as a later meeting over a cup of tea.  And the pair admitted sharing the phone number for Trump’s transition team, who helped set up his White House, with the Russian ambassador, among other officials. But Mr Wigmore denied receiving any money for the Brexit campaign saying there was “not one penny or rouble” donated by the Kremlin to Leave.EU. And Banks dismissed calls for a police inquiry asking “what is the crime? I’d like to know what the police are going to investigate - lunch with the Russian ambassador?”  Although the billionaire did accept there may have been some attempts by Russia to influence the outcome of the referendum on a “low level”. Earlier today in the House of Commons, Labour former Cabinet minister Ben Bradshaw asked Theresa May to launch a full police inquiry into the alleged links.  He said: “Is it not now time for a full police inquiry into the relationship between the Kremlin and the Leave campaign in the EU referendum ?”   But the Prime Minister said that it was a matter for the police to decide whether or not to launch an inquiry. Former Labour minister Liam Byrne echoed calls for a proper investigation. He said: “I think the majority in this House will welcome the overwhelming majority in the G7 not to let Russia back to the top table. But Russia is now seeking to exert its influence through the back door and we learnt about the scale of that over this weekend.”

story: NewsBoy, 15, becomes first to have internet gaming addiction recognised by NHS after missing a year of schoolKendal Parmar’s son was kept in hospital for eight weeks and has missed a year of school because of his “all-consuming” addiction&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmy-Clare Martin20:12, 11 JUN 2018Updated20:56, 11 JUN 2018NewsMum Kendal Parmar has battled for three years for help after her son's condition became so severe he stopped going out (Image: Geoff Pugh)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy of 15 is set to be &shydiagnosed as the first NHS-recognised internet gaming addict. World's first celeb chef's 123rd birthday honoured with Google DoodleThe culinary expert, known as 'la mere Brazier', was the first woman to earn three Michelin stars in 1933 and turned Lyon into France's capital of gastronomy&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter08:45, 12 JUN 2018Updated08:55, 12 JUN 2018NewsToday would have been Eugénie Brazier's 123rd birthday (Image: Lyon Public Library)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Google Doodle for June 12 celebrates what would be the 123rd birthday of Eug&eacutenie Brazier - one of the most famous chefs in French history. In 1933 Brazier became the first woman to earn three coveted Michelin stars and helped turn Lyon into France's capital of gastronomy . Known as as 'la mere Brazier', the then-26-year old opened her first restaurant in 1921 and helped to turn Lyonnaise cuisine into a national phenomenon. title: grieving mum reveals how spice
story: NewsGrieving mum reveals how Spice drug turned angelic 'Milky Bar Kid' son into disturbed addict who died at 36David Richardson had been released from prison a few weeks before his death, having developed an addiction to Spice&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNeal Keeling21:15, 11 JUN 2018Updated21:27, 11 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heartbroken mum has revealed how Spice turned her angelic 'Milky Bar Kid' son into a mentally ill addict who died aged just 36. David Richardson had been released from prison just a few weeks before he died, having developed an addiction to the drug. Despite being caught using Spice two dozen times in jail, he was released early from a four-year sentence, still in the grip of the drug. His inquest heard evidence from the probation service that ‘it was agreed that if he could remain drug free for two months, consideration would be given’ to release on licence. However, David was freed in November - weeks after the last time he was caught. Just over a month after that early release, David was dead.   In his final letter to his mother, written from prison, he described how much he was looking forward to seeing his two children, Manchester Evening News reports .  “How my little (beauties) doing. I don’t half miss them...I can’t wait for this Christmas. We’re gonna have a good’en.” The prisoner and his mother, Maureen, had a plan for Christmas Eve. “I was getting him a Santa suit,” she says. “He was going to come to my house on Christmas Eve, and then see his children to surprise them with presents.” But on December 22, 2016, David was killed. He walked up the M602 at Eccles, at night, and then on an unlit stretch of the M60 at Junction 12, Worsley, where he was hit by a car. A year-and-a-half on, Maureen is adamant that her son was too dependent on Spice and other drugs to be released from prison, and cannot understand how the authorities thought he was fit for release.  While a pupil at St John Fisher Primary in Woodhouse Park, and then St Paul’s RC High in Wythenshawe, David got his nickname - ‘Milky’ - due to his likeness, as a blond lad with round glasses, to The Milky Bar Kid in the chocolate TV advert. It was a name which stuck with him for life, until it ended, aged 36. It was even used on the order of service for his funeral. Maureen is the first to admit that for much of his adult life, her son was no angel. His transformation from the innocent, well-dressed boy, shown in his picture for his confirmation into the Roman Catholic church, to a drug-dependent, disturbed young man was tragically swift. His drug use began at the age of 16, smoking cannabis. But by his early 20s he was using heroin. He turned to theft to finance the habit, picking up more than 20 convictions. But it was Spice - the drug notorious for its dramatic effect on vulnerable users - that took him to his lowest ebb.  “I saw him in prison and I was really worried about him as he was so thin,” Maureen says. “I found out he was selling his dinners in prison and his food to get Spice. “He had to take ‘slaps’ - which is where he gets beaten up by other prisoners and then the assault gets put on Youtube. Your reward is you get Spice. “He was receiving threats at one point while in prison. Some drugs were dropped in the exercise yard by a drone. David picked them up and was supposed to be looking after them for somebody in his cell. “But, being David, it was like putting a kid in a sweet shop. He took all that Spice himself and ended up owing a drug dealer over &pound1,000.” At his inquest, Maureen learnt that between April 2014 and October 2016, David was caught using Spice 24 times in prison. “The 24 times were only the times he was caught using it. I think he was using it daily,” Maureen says. Spice was designed as a synthetic alternative to cannabis. But its effects are much more dramatic than the drug it was designed to mimic. Leaving users in zombie-like catatonic states and triggering psychotic episodes, users have said it is stronger than heroin and crack cocaine. It has gained popularity with vulnerable populations - the homeless and prison inmates - in the last five years, and for a period could be legally bought in shops.  By the time it was outlawed in spring 2016, many were hooked. For someone like David - who was diagnosed in 2009 with depression, pyschosis, and schizophrenia - being introduced to Spice was disastrous. He had shown himself to be capable of beating drugs before - but each time would be pulled back in by bad company. “In his mid 20s I got him to move up to near me in Bolton,” Maureen says. “We got him a little job, because I live near a village and he worked in a pound shop. He loved that job and stopped using hard drugs. “But then he moved back to Wythenshawe and started taking crack cocaine. I used to see him periodically and didn’t realise how bad he had gone.” It was that cocaine addiction that led to David committing robbery and being jailed for four years. But in prison he got no chance to get clean, because Spice was readily available. Following his release from HMP Risley in Warrington, the deterioration in David’s mental health and the extent of his drug problem was apparent. On morning of the day he died, David admitted to hostel staff that he had taken diazepam which was not prescribed to him - breaching the conditions of his licence. Maureen said: “That day, in my opinion, they should have phoned an ambulance with a view to him being sectioned for his own safety. It was known that diazepam had been a trigger for his offending in the past.” In the early evening of December 22, David left the hostel by climbing along the rear wall. He was seen on the M602, where cars dodged him. Great Manchester Police’s helicopter was scrambled to look for him. But at about 7.40pm he was struck by a car.

title: primary schools urge parents keep
story: NewsPrimary schools urge parents to keep their children away from violent shooter game Fortnite amid 'addiction' claimsFortnite is affecting students' concentration and is behind a rise in poor behaviour, teachers say - as MPs pledge to do more to restrict young people from playing the game&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatthew BarbourNeil Murphy07:05, 12 JUN 2018NewsA screenshot shot from Fortnite (Image: Epic Games / SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrimary school heads across Britain have urged their pupils to stay away from 'highly-addictive' video game Fortnite. Worried parents have raised concerns about the hugely popular app, which has reportedly caused issues in children as young as seven. Teachers say the violent game is behind an increase in poor behaviour by students and is distracting pupils from their work. One school in Bristol issued a warning to parents on their Facebook page about the dangers on the video game, the Daily Mail reported. It wrote: “We’ve heard some of our children, including in Year 3, are playing a game online called Fortnite ... if your child is playing this game talk to them and make sure you know what they are doing.”  A school in Stoke-on-Trent also sent a letter to parents saying discussions about Fornite are so common in classrooms that they are distracting children from their learning. Concerned MPs have also waded into the argument and say more must be done to enforce age restrictions online  Nigel Huddleston, who represents Mid Worcestershire for the Conservative Party, said he was ‘horrified’ to hear stories about the game. He said: The Government is going to be making it increasingly difficult for children to see inappropriate content. Fortnite, which can be downloaded for free to mobile phones or computers, pits gamers against each other in a battle-type scenario, only finishing when only one player is left alive. Its exaggerated gameplay and cartoon-like depiction of violence has resulted in it becoming one of the internet's most popular games. Over 40 million have &shydownloaded the so-called &shysurvival shooter game since it was launched last July, sparking &shyrecord numbers of digital addiction.

title: revealed five international food franchises
story: NewsRevealed: The five international food franchises set to take the UK by stormPeruvian sanguches, completos and plátano mixto have been tipped as some of the foods that are likely to disrupt the fast food scene across the world&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMirror21:13, 11 JUN 2018NewsFood franchises like the Californian Burrito Company are set to hit the UK (Image: comercialesLDT)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe next big food franchise will come out of Latin America, experts have claimed, with a number of chains eyeing up global dominance in the next few years. Peruvian sanguches, completos and pl&aacutetano mixto have been tipped as some of the foods that are likely to disrupt the fast food scene across the world. Hispanic takes on hot dogs and doughnuts have also been cited as potential disrupter franchises. Western franchises have dominated the fast food sector across the world up to now, with McDonald’s, Burger King and Subway among the biggest companies in the world. Krispy Kreme was launched this century and now has over 400 sites across the US, with the doughnuts also widely supplied in garages and convenience stores around the world.  But recent research published in the International Business Review suggests the global franchise picture is changing. The research focused on the huge expansion of Brazilian franchises as well as others in Latin America. And according to Leonardo Gonz&aacutelez Dell&aacuten, the fast food scene is ripe for expansion. He said: “The bottom line is that franchises that originate in emerging markets are doing better in other emerging markets than ones that originate in more economically developed countries (MEDCs).  “This is because these businesses do not see high levels of corruption or inefficiencies in doing business as unacceptable obstacles to opening up. “Indeed, the evidence suggests that Brazilian franchise chains, in food and other sectors, do not see corruption as necessarily inhibiting their ability to do business in emerging markets and the least developed countries in Latin America. “In short, they are better able to deal with problems around contracts, complex or contradictory regulations and political instability.  “More generally, emerging market multinationals (MNEs) are more prevalent in less developed countries compared with traditional MNEs – they turn their own experience into a competitive advantage. “With these business experiences behind the teams who have made a success in the Latin America look set to take the world by surprise”.

title: tesco security guard ignored children
story: NewsTesco security guard 'refused to help two children stuck inside hot car due to data protection'A paramedic has told how he spotted the youngsters "sweating away" inside the parked vehicle in Lydney, Gloucestershire&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJohn Glover15:25, 11 JUN 2018Updated16:13, 11 JUN 2018NewsTesco is investigating the claims made by a paramedic (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA paramedic claims a Tesco security guard refused to help two unattended children trapped inside a hot car because of their concerns over data protection. The paramedic has told how he spotted the youngsters sweating away inside a sealed parked car as temperatures hit 27C. Fearing for their safety, he noted the registration and went inside the store in Lydney, Gloucestershire, to alert the driver. But he claimed he was told by a security guard that the information could not be used because of data protection. Tesco has told him it will investigate the incident. The paramedic returned to the car and was about to call police to tell them he was going to break in to save life when the children's mother returned. At a starting temperature of 27C, the heat inside a sealed car is likely to exceed 38C within 20 minutes. After half an hour it could be approaching 48C.  He complained about the “awful” experience on Sunday afternoon in a post on Tesco's Facebook page. He wrote: “My wife, daughter and I popped in for a few bits following a day out. “We parked in one of the parent and child spaces and immediately noticed the black car next to us with two unattended young children in it, sweating away. “The thermometer in our silver car read 27C so I can’t imagine how hot they must have been sealed in that black car.  He added: I immediately went to a member of staff who was in the car park, he took the registration and went to do an announcement for the parent. “We also mentioned it to the security guard. Very worryingly his response was, ‘Oh we can’t do anything about that for data protection reasons'. “He then stopped the other member of staff from taking any action. He then said he would look into it. “I was waiting for an announcement to come out whilst we did our shopping, but nothing ever came.  He wrote: “It turns out the security guard chose to ignore the situation and decided to make no attempt to help the children. “This is incredibly dangerous, the mother should be ashamed of herself but so should the Tesco security guard. The man, who lists his occupation as a paramedic clinical adviser with Care UK, said that as a paramedic he is well aware of how quickly the children could have become unconscious and died. He added: “Tesco, I’m disgusted. This translates roughly to, ‘We would rather let those children die of heat stroke or be abducted than use our PA system’.
